It sounds really tough to have anxiety come on so suddenly.  It's completely understandable that you're feeling depressed when anxiety is impacting your life.  It's great that you're looking for ways to manage it.

To manage anxiety, it helps to look at different areas of your life.  Your therapist is right,  things like eating, sleeping, exercise, and hobbies can make a big difference.  Maybe you could try scheduling some regular time for physical activity, even a short walk, or a relaxing hobby, like drawing or listening to music.  Keeping a regular sleep schedule is also helpful.  Try to go to bed and wake up around the same time each day, even on weekends, to help regulate your body's natural rhythm.

Small changes can make a big difference.  Have you considered keeping a journal to track your anxiety levels and what seems to trigger it?  That way you can notice patterns and see what might be helpful.  You could also talk to your doctor or a therapist about strategies to help you manage these feelings.  It's important to remember that there are tools and strategies that can be effective.  It takes time and effort, but you don't have to go through this alone.  You've got this.

Question: I started having anxiety three months ago. I'm new to having anxiety, and it's making me depressed.

Answer: One of the first steps is to manage anxiety and depression symptoms are to establish a good self-care routine. Start with the most basic things: Eating balanced meals, sleeping at from 6-8 hours and exercise at least 30 minutes a day. These will help you to regulate the chemical imbalance that affects your mood, plus exercising gives you time to vent and be distracted from your thoughts.

Question: I have anxieties about everyday stressors, i.e. finances, work, relationships, kids, and maintaining a household.

Answer: Something to remember about anxiety is that it's a useful and necessary response to stressors, and we all have a level of anxiety that falls somewhere on the spectrum from very slight to very overwhelming. Anxiety is our brain's way of prompting us to deal with the stress in our lives by getting us geared up for action. Some helpful ways of managing anxiety are actually very simple. The first I'd recommend is a calm breathing technique - breathe in for 4-5 seconds, and then out for 7-8 seconds.
